bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

An authorial note at the top of the manuscript is written to the editor of the Critic and signed by Whitman. Elsewhere on the Archive, we have transcribed this note separately as a distinct piece of correspondence.

bibl.author: Unknown
bibl.title: Unknown
bibl.note: The article quoted here probably first appeared in London, as some of the many reprints in US newspapers include the dateline "London, December 14" (1886). The particular reprinting that Whitman clipped has not been located.

body.note: follow copy—punctuation&c—If possible send me a proof Saturday night—which I will return Sunday night WW—Camden New Jersey
body.head: A Word about Tennyson
body.p:
¶ Beautiful as the song was, the original "Locksley Hall" of half a century ago seems was essentially morbid, heart⹀broken, finding fault with every thing, especially the fact of money's being made (as it ever must be, and perhaps should be) the para-
mountparamount matter in worldly affairs.

lg.l: ("Every door is barr'd with gold, and opens but to golden keys.")

body.p: ]First, a father, having fallen in battle, his child, (the singer)

lg.l: was left a trampled orphan, and a selfish uncle's ward."

body.p:
]Of course love ensues. The woman woman in the chant or monologue proves a false one; and as far as appears the ideal of Woman, ‸ in the poet's reflections, is a false one, at any rate for America. Woman is not "the lesser man." (The heart is not the brain.) The best of the piece of fifty years since is its concluding line:
    
    

    
    

    2
     type 

"For the mighty wind arises roaring seaward, and I go."

] Then for ‸ this current 1886-'7, comes a a just⹀out se- quelsequel, which, ( as an apparently authentic summary says), "rReviews
the life of mankind during the past sixty years, and comes to the conclusion that its boasted progress is of doubtful credit to the world in general and to England in particular. A cynical vein of denunciation of democratic opinions and aspirations runs throughout the poem, in marked contrast with the spirit of the "Locksley Hall" of the poet's youth."‸ "/ Among the most striking lines ‸ of this sequel are the following:
smaller type
smaller type
Envy wears the mask of love, and, laughing
sober fact to scorn,
Cries to weakest as to strongest, "Ye are equals,
equal-born."
Equal born! Oh yes, if yonder hill be level with
the flat.
Charm us, orator, till the lion look no larger
than the cat;
Till the cat, through that mirage of overheated
language, loom
Larger than the lion Demos—end in working its
own doom.
Tuble nature heel over head, and, yelling with
the yelling street,
Set the feet above the brain and swear the brain
is in the feet.
Bring the old Dark Ages back, without the faith,
without the hope
Beneath the State, the Church, the throne, and
roll their ruins down the slope.

]I should say that all this is a legitimate consequence of the tone and convictions of the earlier ‸standards and points of view. Then some other reflections, down to the hard⹀pan of this sort of thing.

The course of progressive politics, (democracy) is so certain and resistless not only in America but in Europe, that we can well afford the warning calls, threats, checks, neutralizings, in ‸imaginative literature, or any department of such deep⹀sounding and
3 high⹀soaring voices as Carlyle's and Tennyson's. Nay, the dangers, blindnesses, excesses, of the prevalent tendency—the ‸dangers of the urgent trendsn of our times—are such that, in my opinion, we need such voices almost more than any. I should, too, call it a signal instance of democratic humanity's luck that it has such enemies to contend with—so cand -didcandid, so fe fervid, so heroic. But why do I say enemy? Upon the whole is not Tennyson—and was not Carlyle—(like thean honest and stern physician)—athe true friend ? of thisour age?

¶Let me assume to pass verdict, or perhaps momentary judgment, on this poet, for the United States ‸on this poet——(a removed and distant position giving some advantages over a nigh one.) What is Tennyson's service to his age, to humanity,race, times, and especially to America?
